Statistically significant improvements in both depression and anxiety were found at 3 month follow-up.
Compared with the control group, groups exposed to an age progression experienced more negative affect, and individuals in the self-aged condition reported greater aging anxiety.

Using data from 139 patients (45.5 women; mean age = 32.18 years) participating in a 12-week transdiagnostic cognitive-behavioral therapy program for anxiety, weekly assessments of anxiety severity were examined to investigate the extent to which level of anxiety and rate of improvement predicted treatment discontinuation.
Convergent validity was supported by expected relationships of Perceived Stress Scale-10 scores to measures of anxiety and depression.
